<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>See discussion of events affecting the comparability of statement of earnings amounts in the Consolidated Operating Results section of the following Discussion
and Analysis.</I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
favorable net impact of lower asset impairment, exit and implementation costs on earnings and diluted EPS from continuing operations is due primarily to the following: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Restructuring Program</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;The Company announced a three-year restructuring program in January&nbsp;2004. During the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, the Company recorded pre-tax charges of $297&nbsp;million ($199&nbsp;million after-tax) and $633&nbsp;million
($410&nbsp;million after-tax), respectively, for the restructuring plan, including pre-tax implementation costs of $87&nbsp;million and $50&nbsp;million, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Asset Impairment Charges</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;During 2005, the Company sold its fruit snacks assets for approximately $30&nbsp;million and
incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $93&nbsp;million ($60&nbsp;million after-tax) in recognition of the sale. During December&nbsp;2005, the Company reached
agreements to sell certain assets in Canada and a small biscuit brand in the U.S. These transactions closed in the first quarter of 2006. The Company incurred 2005 pre-tax asset impairment
charges of $176&nbsp;million ($80&nbsp;million after-tax) in recognition of the pending sales. These charges, which include the write-off of all associated intangible
assets, were recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statement of earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment Impairment</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;In November&nbsp;2004, following discussions with the Company's joint venture partner in Turkey and an
independent valuation of its equity investment, it was determined that a permanent decline in value had occurred. This valuation resulted in a $47&nbsp;million non-cash
pre-tax charge ($31&nbsp;million after-tax). This charge was recorded as marketing, administration and research costs on the consolidated statement of earnings. During 2005,
the Company's interest in the joint venture was sold. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>21</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=22,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=251304,FOLIO='21',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DI1135A.;10',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_di1135_1_22"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
further details on the restructuring program or asset impairment and implementation costs, see Note&nbsp;3 to the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Business Environment
section of the following Discussion and Analysis. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gains on Sales of Businesses</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;The favorable impact on earnings and diluted EPS from continuing operations is due primarily to
the gain on sale of the U.K. desserts assets in 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Lower Effective Income Tax Rate</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;The Company's reported effective income tax rate decreased by 2.9&nbsp;percentage points to
29.4%. The 2005 effective tax rate reflects several benefits, including the settlement of an outstanding U.S. tax claim of $24&nbsp;million; $82&nbsp;million from the resolution of outstanding
items in the Company's international operations; and $33&nbsp;million in tax impacts associated with the sale of a U.S. biscuit brand. The 2005 rate also includes a $53&nbsp;million aggregate
benefit from the domestic manufacturers' deduction provision and the dividend repatriation provision of the American Jobs Creation Act. The tax provision in 2004 includes an
$81&nbsp;million favorable resolution of an outstanding tax item and the reversal of $35&nbsp;million of tax accruals that were no longer required due to tax events that occurred during 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Currency</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;The favorable currency impact on earnings and diluted EPS from continuing operations is due primarily to the weakness
of the U.S. dollar versus the euro, the Canadian dollar, the Brazilian real and certain other currencies. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operations</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;The decrease in results from operations was due primarily to the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Lower
income at Kraft North America Commercial, reflecting higher commodity and benefit costs, and increased marketing spending, partially offset by higher pricing and
favorable volume/mix (including the benefit from the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week).
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Lower
income at Kraft International Commercial, reflecting higher commodity and developing market infrastructure costs, partially offset by higher pricing and favorable
volume/mix (including the benefit from the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week). </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
further details, see the Consolidated Operating Results and Operating Results by Business Segment sections of the following Discussion and Analysis. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>2006 Forecasted Results</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;In January&nbsp;2006, the Company announced that it expects 2006 full-year diluted EPS
in a range of $1.38 to $1.43. This forecast includes anticipated charges of approximately $0.50 for costs related to its restructuring program and an effective income tax rate of approximately 33%. It
does not reflect the potential impacts from the resolution of outstanding tax audits. The factors described in the section entitled Risk Factors in Part&nbsp;1, Item 1A of this Annual Report on
Form&nbsp;10-K represent continuing risks to these forecasts. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Discussion and Analysis  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Note&nbsp;2 to the consolidated financial statements includes a summary of the significant accounting policies and methods used in the preparation of the
Company's consolidated financial statements. In most instances, the Company must use an accounting policy or method because it is the only policy or method permitted under accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States of America ("U.S. GAAP"). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
preparation of all financial statements includes the use of estimates and assumptions that affect a number of amounts included in the Company's financial statements, including, among
other things, employee benefit costs and income taxes. The Company bases its estimates on historical experience and other assumptions that it believes are reasonable. If actual amounts are ultimately
different from previous estimates, the revisions are included in the Company's consolidated results of operations for </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>22</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=23,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=944320,FOLIO='22',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DI1135A.;10',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_di1135_1_23"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>the
period in which the actual amounts become known. Historically, the aggregate differences, if any, between the Company's estimates and actual amounts in any year have not had a significant impact
on the Company's consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
selection and disclosure of the Company's critical accounting policies and estimates have been discussed with the Company's Audit Committee. The following is a review of the more
significant assumptions and estimates, as well as the accounting policies and methods used in the preparation of the Company's consolidated financial statements: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee Benefit Plans.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note&nbsp;15 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company provides a range
of benefits to its employees and retired employees, including pensions, postretirement health care benefits and postemployment benefits (primarily severance). The Company records amounts relating to
these plans based on calculations specified by U.S. GAAP, which include various actuarial assumptions, such as discount rates, assumed rates of return on plan assets, compensation increases, turnover
rates and health care cost trend rates. The Company reviews its actuarial assumptions on an annual basis and makes modifications to the assumptions based on current rates and trends when it is deemed
appropriate to do so. As permitted by U.S. GAAP, any effect of the modifications is generally amortized over future periods. The Company believes that the assumptions utilized in recording its
obligations under its plans, which are presented in Note&nbsp;15 to the consolidated financial statements, are reasonable based on its experience and advice from its actuaries. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, the Company recorded the following amounts in the consolidated statements of earnings for employee benefit plans: </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>882</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>635</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>347</FONT></TD>

<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
2005 net expense for employee benefit plans of $882&nbsp;million increased by $247&nbsp;million over the 2004 amount. The cost increase primarily relates to higher U.S. pension
plan costs, including higher amortization of the unrecognized net loss from experience differences, a lower expected return on plan assets, a lower discount rate assumption and higher settlement
losses as employees retired or left during 2005. The 2004 net expense for employee benefit plans of $635&nbsp;million increased by $288&nbsp;million over the 2003 amount. This cost increase
primarily relates to increased postemployment benefit costs, resulting from several workforce reduction programs during 2004 as part of the overall restructuring program ($167&nbsp;million), and a
lowering of the Company's discount rate
assumption on its pension and postretirement benefit plans, partially offset by the impact of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003 discussed below. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2003, the United States enacted into law the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003 (the "Act"). The Act establishes a prescription drug
benefit under Medicare, known as "Medicare Part&nbsp;D," and a federal subsidy to sponsors of retiree health care benefit plans that provide a benefit that is at least actuarially equivalent to
Medicare Part&nbsp;D. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
May&nbsp;2004, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued FASB Staff Position No.&nbsp;106-2, "Accounting and Disclosure Requirements Related to the
Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003" ("FSP 106-2"). FSP 106-2 requires companies to account for the effect of the subsidy on benefits
attributable to past service as an actuarial experience gain and as </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>23</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=24,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=520416,FOLIO='23',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DI1135A.;10',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_di1135_1_24"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>a
reduction of the service cost component of net postretirement health care costs for amounts attributable to current service, if the benefit provided is at least actuarially equivalent to Medicare
Part&nbsp;D. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company adopted FSP 106-2 in the third quarter of 2004. The impact for 2005 and 2004 was a reduction of pre-tax net postretirement health care costs and an
increase in net earnings of $55&nbsp;million and $24&nbsp;million, respectively. In addition, as of July&nbsp;1, 2004, the Company reduced its accumulated postretirement benefit obligation for
the subsidy related to benefits attributed to past service by $315&nbsp;million and decreased its unrecognized actuarial losses by the same amount. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2005, for the U.S. pension and postretirement plans, the Company reduced its discount rate assumption from 5.75% to 5.60%. The Company presently anticipates that
assumption changes, coupled with the amortization of deferred gains and losses will result in an increase in 2006 pre-tax benefit expense of approximately $80&nbsp;million, or
approximately $0.03 per share. The expected increase in benefit expense is prior to the consideration of any impact of the expanded restructuring program. While the Company does not presently
anticipate a change in its 2006 assumptions, as a sensitivity measure, a fifty-basis point decline (increase) in the Company's discount rate would increase (decrease) the Company's U.S. pension and
postretirement expense by approximately $72&nbsp;million. Similarly, a fifty-basis point decrease (increase) in the expected return on plan assets would increase (decrease) the Company's pension
expense for the U.S. pension plans by approximately $31&nbsp;million. See Note&nbsp;15 to the consolidated financial statements for a sensitivity discussion of the assumed health care cost trend
rates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue Recognition.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As required by U.S. GAAP, the Company recognizes revenues, net of sales incentives, and including
shipping and handling charges billed to customers, upon shipment or
delivery of goods when title and risk of loss pass to customers. Shipping and handling costs are classified as part of cost of sales. Provisions and allowances for estimated sales returns and bad
debts are also recorded in the Company's consolidated financial statements. The amounts recorded for these provisions and related allowances are not significant to the Company's consolidated financial
position or results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation, Amortization and Goodwill Valuation.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company depreciates property, plant and equipment and amortizes
definite life intangibles using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company is required to conduct an annual review of goodwill and intangible assets for potential impairment. Goodwill impairment testing requires a comparison between the carrying
value and fair value of each reporting unit. If the carrying value exceeds the fair value, goodwill is considered impaired. The amount of impairment loss is measured as the difference between the
carrying value and implied fair value of goodwill, which is determined using discounted cash flows. Impairment testing for non-amortizable intangible assets requires a comparison between
the fair value and carrying value of the intangible asset. If the carrying value exceeds fair value, the intangible asset is considered impaired and is reduced to fair value. These calculations may be
affected by the market conditions noted below in the Business Environment section, as well as interest rates, general economic conditions and projected growth rates. During the first quarter of 2005,
the Company completed its annual review of goodwill and intangible assets and no impairment charges resulted from this review. However, as part of the sale or pending sale of certain Canadian assets
and two brands, the Company recorded non-cash pre-tax asset impairment charges of $269&nbsp;million in 2005, which included impairment of goodwill and intangible assets of
$13&nbsp;million and $118&nbsp;million, respectively, as well as $138&nbsp;million of asset write-downs. During 2004, the Company's annual review of goodwill and intangible assets resulted in a
$29&nbsp;million non-cash pre-tax charge related to an intangible asset impairment for a small confectionery business in the United States and certain brands in Mexico. A
portion of this charge, $17&nbsp;million, was reclassified to earnings from discontinued operations on the consolidated statement of earnings in the fourth quarter of 2004. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>24</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=25,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=554367,FOLIO='24',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DI1135A.;10',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_di1135_1_25"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
remaining charge was recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the 2004 consolidated statement of earnings. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Impairment of Long-Lived Assets.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company reviews long-lived assets, including amortizable
intangible assets, for impairment whenever events or changes in business circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the assets may not be fully recoverable. The Company performs undiscounted
operating cash flow analyses to determine if an impairment exists. These analyses are affected by interest rates, general economic conditions and projected growth rates. For purposes of recognition
and measurement of an impairment for assets held for use, the Company groups assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which cash flows are separately identifiable. If an impairment is determined
to exist, any related impairment loss is calculated based on fair value. Impairment losses on assets to be disposed of, if any, are based on the estimated proceeds to be received, less costs of
disposal. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Marketing and Advertising Costs.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As required by U.S. GAAP, the Company records marketing costs as an expense in the year to
which such costs relate. The Company does not defer amounts on its year-end consolidated balance sheet with respect to marketing costs. The Company expenses advertising costs as incurred.
Consumer incentive and trade promotion activities are recorded as a reduction of revenues based on amounts estimated as being due to customers and consumers at the end of a period, based principally
on historical utilization and redemption rates. For interim reporting purposes, advertising and consumer incentive expenses are charged to operations as a percentage of volume, based on estimated
volume and related expense for the full year. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Related Party Transactions.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note&nbsp;4 to the consolidated financial statements, Altria
Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s subsidiary, Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., provides the Company with various services, including planning, legal, treasury, auditing, insurance, human resources, office
of the secretary, corporate affairs, information technology, aviation and tax services. Billings for these services, which were based on the cost to Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. to provide
such services and a management fee, were $237&nbsp;million, $310&nbsp;million and $318&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively. The Company
performed at a similar cost various functions in 2005 that previously had been provided by Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., resulting in a lower service charge in 2005. These costs were paid to
Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. monthly. Although the cost of these services cannot be quantified on a stand-alone basis, management has assessed that the billings are reasonable based on the
level of support provided by Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., and that they reflect all services provided. The cost and nature of the services are reviewed annually by the Company's Audit
Committee, which is comprised of independent directors. The effects of these transactions are included in operating cash flows in the Company's consolidated statements of cash flows. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2005, the Company repatriated certain foreign earnings as part of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s dividend repatriation plan under provisions of the American Jobs Creation Act.
Increased taxes for this repatriation of $21&nbsp;million, were reimbursed by Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. The reimbursement was reported in the Company's financial statements as an increase to
additional paid-in capital. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2005, the Company purchased an airport hangar and certain personal property located at the hangar in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, from Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc.
for an aggregate purchase price of approximately $3.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2004, the Company purchased two corporate aircraft from Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. for an aggregate purchase price of approximately $47&nbsp;million. The
Company also entered into an Aircraft Management Agreement with Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. in December&nbsp;2004, pursuant to which Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. agreed to
perform aircraft management, pilot services, maintenance and other aviation services for the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, the Company had short-term amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. of $652&nbsp;million and $227&nbsp;million, respectively.
The amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>25</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=26,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=780648,FOLIO='25',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DI1135A.;10',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_di1135_1_26"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>generally
include accrued dividends, taxes and service fees. The increase from 2004 primarily reflects the timing of payments. Interest on intercompany borrowings is based on the applicable London
Interbank Offered Rate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Taxes.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company accounts for income taxes in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS")
No.&nbsp;109, "Accounting for Income Taxes." The U.S. accounts of the Company are included in the consolidated federal income tax return of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. Income taxes are generally
computed on a separate company basis. To the extent that foreign tax credits, capital losses and other credits generated by the Company, which cannot currently be utilized on a separate company basis,
are utilized in Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated federal income tax return, the benefit is recognized in the calculation of the Company's provision for income taxes. Based on the Company's
current estimate, this benefit is calculated to be approximately $225&nbsp;million, $70&nbsp;million and $100&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003,
respectively. The increase in 2005 is driven primarily by dividend repatriations and certain legal entity reorganizations. The benefit is dependent on a variety of tax attributes that have a tendency
to vary year to year. The Company makes payments to, or is reimbursed by, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. for the tax effects resulting from its inclusion in Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated federal
income tax return including current taxes payable and net changes in tax provisions. The provision for income taxes is based on domestic and international statutory income tax rates and tax planning
opportunities available to the Company in the jurisdictions in which it operates. Significant judgment is required in determining income tax provisions and in evaluating tax positions. The Company
establishes additional provisions for income taxes when, despite the belief that existing tax positions are fully supportable, there remain certain positions that are likely to be challenged and that
may not be sustained on review by tax authorities. The Company evaluates and potentially adjusts these provisions in light of changing facts and circumstances. The consolidated tax provision includes
the impact of changes to accruals that are considered appropriate. Upon the closure of current and future tax audits in various jurisdictions, significant income tax accrual reversals could continue
to occur, which could trigger cash reimbursements from Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
October, 2004, the American Jobs Creation Act ("the Jobs Act") was signed into law. The Jobs Act includes a deduction for 85% of certain foreign earnings that are repatriated. In
2005, the Company repatriated approximately $500&nbsp;million of earnings under the provisions of the Jobs Act. Deferred taxes had previously been provided for a portion of the dividends to be
remitted. The reversal of the deferred taxes more than offset the tax costs to repatriate the earnings and resulted in a net tax reduction of $28&nbsp;million in the consolidated income tax
provision during 2005, the majority of which was recorded during the second quarter. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Jobs Act also provides tax relief to U.S. domestic manufacturers by providing a tax deduction related to a percentage of the lesser of "qualified production activities income" or
taxable income. The deduction, which was 3% in 2005, increases to 9% by 2010. In accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;109,
the Company will recognize these benefits in the year earned. The tax benefit in 2005 was approximately $25&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company is regularly audited by federal, state and foreign tax authorities, and these audits are at various stages at any given time. The Company anticipates several domestic and
foreign audits will close in 2006 with expected favorable settlements. Any tax contingency reserves in excess of additional assessed liabilities will be reversed at the time the audits close. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Consolidation.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., as well as its wholly-owned and
majority-owned subsidiaries. Investments in which Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. exercises significant influence (20%&#151;50% ownership interest), are accounted for under the equity method of
accounting. Investments in which Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. has an ownership interest of less than 20%, or does not exercise significant influence, are accounted for with the cost method of accounting.
All intercompany transactions and balances between and among Kraft's subsidiaries have been eliminated. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>26</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=27,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=453520,FOLIO='26',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DI1135A.;10',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_di1135_1_27"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Transactions
between any of the Company's businesses and Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and its affiliates are included in the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Business Environment  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is subject to a number of challenges that may adversely affect its businesses. These challenges, which are discussed below and under the "Risk
Factors" section in Part&nbsp;1, Item 1A of this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K, include: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>fluctuations
in commodity prices;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>movements
of foreign currencies;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>competitive
challenges in various products and markets, including price gaps with competitor products and the increasing price-consciousness of consumers;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>a
rising cost environment and the limited ability to increase prices;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>a
trend toward increasing consolidation in the retail trade and consequent pricing pressure and inventory reductions;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>a
growing presence of discount retailers, primarily in Europe, with an emphasis on own-label products;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>changing
consumer preferences, including diet trends;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>competitors
with different profit objectives and less susceptibility to currency exchange rates; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>concerns
and/or regulations regarding food safety, quality and health, including genetically modified organisms, trans-fatty acids and obesity. Increased government
regulation of the food industry could result in increased costs to the Company. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the ordinary course of business, the Company is subject to many influences that can impact the timing of sales to customers, including the timing of holidays and other annual or
special events, seasonality of certain products, significant weather conditions, timing of Company or customer incentive programs and pricing actions, customer inventory programs, Company initiatives
to improve supply chain efficiency, including efforts to align product shipments more closely with consumption by shifting some of its customer marketing programs to a consumption based approach,
financial condition of customers and general economic conditions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fluctuations
in commodity prices can lead to retail price volatility and intense price competition, and can influence consumer and trade buying patterns. During 2005, the Company's
commodity costs on average have been higher than those incurred in 2004 (most notably coffee, nuts, energy and packaging), and have adversely affected earnings. For 2005, the Company had a negative
pre-tax impact from all commodities of approximately $800&nbsp;million as compared with 2004, following an increase of approximately $900&nbsp;million for 2004 compared with 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Restructuring:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January&nbsp;2004, the Company announced a three-year restructuring program, with the objectives of leveraging the Company's global scale,
realigning and lowering its cost structure, and optimizing capacity utilization. As part of this program (which is discussed further in Note&nbsp;3 to the consolidated financial statements), the
Company anticipated the closure or sale of up to 20 plants and the elimination of approximately 6,000 positions. From 2004 through 2006, the Company expects to incur approximately $1.2&nbsp;billion
in pre-tax charges, reflecting asset disposals, severance and other implementation costs, including $297&nbsp;million and $641&nbsp;million incurred in 2005 and 2004, respectively.
Total pre-tax charges for the program incurred through December&nbsp;31, 2005 were $938&nbsp;million and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>27</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=28,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=146941,FOLIO='27',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DI1135A.;10',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_di1135_1_28"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>specific
programs announced will result in the elimination of approximately 5,500 positions. Approximately 60% of the pre-tax charges are expected to require cash payments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, the Company expects to incur approximately $170&nbsp;million in capital expenditures from 2004 through 2006 to implement the restructuring program. From
January&nbsp;2004 through December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company spent $144&nbsp;million, including $98&nbsp;million spent in 2005, in capital to implement the restructuring program. Cost savings
as a result of the restructuring program were approximately $131&nbsp;million in 2005 and $127&nbsp;million in 2004, and were anticipated to reach cumulative annualized cost savings of
approximately $450&nbsp;million by 2006, all of which were expected to be used to support brand-building initiatives. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
January&nbsp;2006, the Company announced plans to expand its restructuring efforts beyond those originally contemplated. Additional pre-tax charges are anticipated to be
$2.5&nbsp;billion from 2006 to 2009, of which approximately $1.6&nbsp;billion are expected to require cash payments. These charges will result in the anticipated closure of up to 20 additional
facilities and the elimination of approximately 8,000 additional positions. Initiatives under the expanded program include additional organizational streamlining and facility closures. The expanded
initiatives are expected to add approximately $700&nbsp;million in annualized cost savings by 2009. Capital expenditures required for the expanded restructuring program will be included within the
Company's overall capital spending budget, which is expected to remain flat in 2006 versus 2005 at $1.2&nbsp;billion. The entire restructuring program is expected to ultimately result in
$3.7&nbsp;billion in pre-tax charges, the closure of up to 40 facilities, the elimination of approximately 14,000 positions and cumulative annualized cost savings at the completion of
the program of approximately $1.15&nbsp;billion. Approximately $2.3&nbsp;billion of the $3.7&nbsp;billion in pre-tax charges are expected to require cash payments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Acquisitions and Dispositions:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;One element of the Company's growth strategy is to strengthen its brand portfolios through a disciplined program of selective acquisitions and divestitures. The
Company is constantly reviewing potential acquisition candidates and from time to time sells businesses to accelerate the shift in its portfolio toward businesses&#151;whether global, regional
or local&#151;that offer the Company a sustainable competitive advantage. The impact of any future acquisition or divestiture could have a material impact on the Company's consolidated
financial position, results of operations or cash flows, and future sales of businesses could in some cases result in losses on sale. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
previously discussed, the Company sold substantially all of its sugar confectionery business in June&nbsp;2005 for pre-tax proceeds of approximately $1.4&nbsp;billion.
The sale included the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Life Savers</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Creme Savers</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Altoids</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Trolli</I></FONT><FONT
SIZE=2> and </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Sugus</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> brands. The Company has
reflected the results of its sugar confectionery business prior to the closing date as discontinued operations on the consolidated statements of earnings for all years presented. The assets related to
the sugar confectionery business were reflected as assets of discontinued operations held for sale on the consolidated balance sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2004. The Company recorded a loss on sale of
discontinued operations of $297&nbsp;million in the second quarter of 2005, related largely to taxes on the transaction. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2004, the Company acquired a U.S.-based beverage business for a total cost of $137&nbsp;million. During 2003, the Company acquired a biscuits business in Egypt and trademarks
associated with a small U.S.-based natural foods business. The total cost of these and other smaller acquisitions was $98&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2005, the Company sold its fruit snacks assets, and incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $93&nbsp;million in recognition of this sale. Additionally, during
2005, the Company sold its U.K. desserts assets, its U.S. yogurt assets, a small business in Colombia, a minor trademark in Mexico and a small equity investment in Turkey. The aggregate proceeds
received from these sales were $238&nbsp;million, on which the Company recorded pre-tax gains of $108&nbsp;million. In December&nbsp;2005, the Company </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=29,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=880020,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DI1135A.;10',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_di1135_1_29"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>announced
the sales of certain Canadian assets and a small U.S. biscuit brand, and incurred pre-tax asset impairment charges of $176&nbsp;million in recognition of these sales. These
transactions closed in the first quarter of 2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2004, the Company sold a Brazilian snack nuts business and trademarks associated with a candy business in Norway. The aggregate proceeds received from the sales of these
businesses were $18&nbsp;million, on which pre-tax losses of $3&nbsp;million were recorded. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2003, the Company sold a European rice business and a branded fresh cheese business in Italy. The aggregate proceeds received from sales of businesses were $96&nbsp;million, on
which the Company recorded pre-tax gains of $31&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
operating results of the businesses acquired and sold, excluding the sugar confectionery business, in the aggregate, were not material to the Company's consolidated financial
position, results of operations or cash flows in any of the periods presented. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=31,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=672620,FOLIO='30',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DK1135A.;21',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1135_1_31"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating income was affected by the following items during 2005, 2004 and 2003: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset impairment, exit and implementation costs&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>As discussed in Note&nbsp;3 to the consolidated financial
statements, during 2005 and 2004, the Company recorded $479&nbsp;million and $603&nbsp;million, respectively, of asset impairment and exit costs on its consolidated statement of earnings.
Additionally, during 2005 and 2004, the Company recorded pre-tax implementation costs of $87&nbsp;million and $50&nbsp;million, respectively. During 2004, the Company also recorded
$47&nbsp;million of pre-tax impairment charges related to its equity investment in a joint venture in Turkey. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
pre-tax asset impairment, exit and implementation costs for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, were included in the operating companies income of the
following segments: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">

</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="31%" ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>

<TH WIDTH="31%" ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=14 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>(in millions)<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="31%"><FONT SIZE=2>U.S. Beverages</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="12%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>9</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=32,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=565634,FOLIO='31',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DK1135A.;21',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1135_1_32"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2003, the Company recorded a pre-tax charge of $6&nbsp;million for asset impairment and exit costs related to the closure of a Nordic snacks plant. This charge was
included in the operating companies income of the Europe, Middle East&nbsp;&amp; Africa segment. </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>(Gains) Losses on Sales of Businesses&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>During 2005, the Company sold its fruit snacks assets, U.K. desserts
assets, U.S. yogurt assets, a small business in Colombia, a minor trademark in Mexico and a small equity investment in Turkey for aggregate pre-tax gains of $108&nbsp;million. During
2004, the Company sold a Brazilian snack nuts business and trademarks associated with a candy business in Norway for aggregate pre-tax losses of $3&nbsp;million. During 2003, the Company
sold a European rice business and a branded fresh cheese business in Italy for aggregate pre-tax gains of $31&nbsp;million. These pre-tax (gains) losses were included in the
operating companies income of the following segments: </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed in Note&nbsp;14 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company's management uses operating companies income, which is defined as operating income before general
corporate expenses and amortization of intangibles, to evaluate segment performance and allocate resources. Management believes it is appropriate to disclose this measure to help investors analyze the
business performance and trends of the various business segments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2005 compared with 2004  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares consolidated operating results for 2005 with 2004. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's 2005 results included 53 weeks of operating results compared with 52 weeks in 2004. The Company estimates that this extra week positively impacted net revenues and
operating income by approximately 2% in 2005 (approximately $625&nbsp;million and $100&nbsp;million, respectively). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume
increased 210&nbsp;million pounds (1.1%), including the benefit of 53 weeks in 2005 results. Excluding all acquisitions and divestitures, and the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of
shipments, volume decreased approximately 1% due primarily to a focus on mix improvement, a SKU reduction program, the impact of higher retail prices on category growth trends in the United States and
declines in certain international countries (most notably Germany), partially offset by new product introductions and growth in developing markets. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $1,945&nbsp;million (6.0%) due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($1,086&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), favorable
currency ($533&nbsp;million), higher net pricing ($453&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing, partially offset by increased promotional spending) and the impact of acquisitions
($42&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of divested businesses ($174&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
income increased $140&nbsp;million (3.0%), due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($479&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), lower asset
impairment and exit costs ($124&nbsp;million), net gains on the sales of businesses ($111&nbsp;million), favorable currency ($90&nbsp;million) and a 2004 equity investment impairment charge
related to a joint venture in Turkey ($47&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher marketing, administration and research costs ($420&nbsp;million, including higher benefit and marketing costs,
as well as costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), higher fixed manufacturing costs </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>32</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=33,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=35011,FOLIO='32',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DK1135A.;21',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1135_1_33"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>($110&nbsp;million),
unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($102&nbsp;million, due primarily to higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending), the net impact of higher
implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($37&nbsp;million), and the impact of divestitures ($33&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Currency
movements increased net revenues by $533&nbsp;million and operating income by $90&nbsp;million. These increases were due primarily to the weakness of the U.S. dollar against
the euro, the Canadian dollar, the Brazilian real and certain other currencies. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's reported effective income tax rate decreased by 2.9&nbsp;percentage points to 29.4%, due primarily to the settlement of an outstanding U.S. tax claim of
$24&nbsp;million; $82&nbsp;million from the resolution of outstanding items in the Company's international operations; and $33&nbsp;million in tax impacts associated with the sale of a U.S.
biscuit brand. The 2005 rate also includes a $53&nbsp;million aggregate benefit from the domestic manufacturers' deduction provision and the dividend repatriation provision of the American Jobs
Creation Act. The tax provision in 2004 included the
$81&nbsp;million favorable resolution of an outstanding tax item and the reversal of $35&nbsp;million of tax accruals that were no longer required due to tax events that occurred during 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings
from continuing operations of $2,904&nbsp;million increased $235&nbsp;million (8.8%), due primarily to higher operating income and a lower income tax rate. Diluted EPS from
continuing operations, which was $1.72, increased by 11.0%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Loss
from discontinued operations, net of income tax, increased $268&nbsp;million, due primarily to a loss on sale of $297&nbsp;million in 2005. The loss from discontinued operations
was due primarily to the recording of additional tax expense that arose from the sale of the sugar confectionery business in the second quarter of 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
earnings of $2,632&nbsp;million decreased $33&nbsp;million (1.2%). Diluted EPS from net earnings, which was $1.55, was equal to 2004. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2004 compared with 2003  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares consolidated operating results for 2004 with 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume
increased 509&nbsp;million pounds (2.8%), due primarily to acquisitions and increased shipments in the U.S. Cheese, Canada&nbsp;&amp; North America Foodservice segment, partially
offset by the impact of divested businesses. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $1,670&nbsp;million (5.5%), due primarily to favorable currency ($838&nbsp;million), higher volume/mix ($560&nbsp;million), higher net pricing
($265&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing, partially offset by increased promotional spending) and the impact of acquisitions ($140&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of
divested businesses ($126&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
income decreased $1,248&nbsp;million (21.3%), due primarily to the pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($597&nbsp;million), unfavorable costs,
net of higher pricing ($442&nbsp;million, due primarily to higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending), higher marketing, administration and research costs ($306&nbsp;million), the
2004 implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($50&nbsp;million), the 2004 equity investment impairment charge relating to a joint venture in Turkey ($47&nbsp;million), the
unfavorable net impact related to gains and losses on the sales of businesses ($34&nbsp;million), higher fixed manufacturing costs ($23&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs) and the impact
of divestitures ($18&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher volume/mix ($187&nbsp;million) and favorable currency ($98&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Currency
movements increased net revenues by $838&nbsp;million and operating income by $98&nbsp;million. These increases were due primarily to the weakness of the U.S. dollar against
the euro and the Canadian dollar. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=34,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=788698,FOLIO='33',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DK1135A.;21',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1135_1_34"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's reported effective income tax rate decreased by 2.6&nbsp;percentage points to 32.3%, resulting from an $81&nbsp;million favorable resolution of an outstanding tax item
and the reversal of $35&nbsp;million of tax accruals that are no longer required due to tax events that occurred during 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings
from continuing operations of $2,669&nbsp;million decreased $710&nbsp;million (21.0%), due primarily to lower operating income, partially offset by a lower effective income
tax rate. Diluted EPS from continuing operations, which was $1.55, decreased by 20.5%. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings
from discontinued operations, net of income tax, decreased $101&nbsp;million, resulting in a net loss of $4&nbsp;million in 2004. The decrease was due primarily to
pre-tax non-cash asset impairment charges in 2004 of $107&nbsp;million ($69&nbsp;million after-tax) and an intangible pre-tax asset impairment
charge of $17&nbsp;million ($11&nbsp;million after-tax). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
earnings of $2,665&nbsp;million decreased $811&nbsp;million (23.3%). Diluted EPS from net earnings, which was $1.55, decreased by 22.9%. </FONT></P>
