<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2005 compared with 2004  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares Kraft North America Commercial's operating results for 2005 with 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume
increased 2.0% including the benefit of 53 weeks in 2005 results. Excluding acquisitions and divestitures, and the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of shipments, volume was essentially
flat. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=35,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=914998,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DK1135A.;21',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1135_1_35"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $1,233&nbsp;million (5.6%) due primarily to higher volume/mix ($873&nbsp;million including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), higher net pricing
($239&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven price increases primarily on coffee, cheese, nuts and meats, partially offset by increased promotional spending), favorable currency
($172&nbsp;million) and the impact of acquisitions ($41&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of divestitures ($97&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $39&nbsp;million (1.0%), due primarily to higher marketing, administration and research costs ($367&nbsp;million, including higher benefit and
marketing costs, as well as costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), higher fixed manufacturing costs ($94&nbsp;million), the net impact of higher implementation costs associated with the
restructuring program ($15&nbsp;million), the impact of divestitures ($9&nbsp;million) and unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($3&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs and
increased promotional spending), partially offset by favorable volume/mix ($364&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), lower pre-tax charges for asset
impairment and exit costs ($56&nbsp;million) and favorable currency ($31&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following discusses operating results within each of Kraft North America Commercial's reportable segments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Beverages.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 4.8% including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of shipments
(approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of growth), due primarily to refreshment beverages, partially offset by a decline in coffee. Refreshment beverages volume increased, due primarily to the 2004
acquisition of Veryfine, partially offset by a shift to lower weight sugar-free powdered beverages. In coffee, volume declined due to the impact of commodity-driven price increases on
category consumption, although volume grew in premium brand coffee. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $297&nbsp;million (11.6%), due primarily to higher pricing and lower promotional spending ($150&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing in coffee),
higher volume/mix ($111&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week) and the impact of the 2004 Veryfine acquisition ($34&nbsp;million). Refreshment beverages net revenues
increased, due primarily to expanded distribution of </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Veryfine</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> and new product introductions in sugar-free powdered beverages. Coffee net
revenues increased, due primarily to increased prices and positive mix driven by volume growth in premium brands. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $21&nbsp;million (4.4%), due primarily to higher marketing, administration and research costs ($101&nbsp;million, including higher marketing and
benefit costs, as well as costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week) and higher fixed manufacturing costs ($12&nbsp;million), partially offset by favorable volume/mix ($76&nbsp;million
including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>week) and higher pricing ($14&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Cheese, Canada&nbsp;&amp; North America Foodservice.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 0.8% including the
53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of shipments (approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of growth), due primarily to the impact of the divestiture of the U.S. yogurt assets and lower shipments in Canada,
partially offset by gains in foodservice. In cheese, volume declined due primarily to the impact of the yogurt divestiture, partially offset by gains in natural cheese, cream cheese, process loaves
and cottage cheese. Volume declined in Canada, due primarily to lower shipments of grocery products, ready-to-drink beverages, coffee and desserts. Volume in the foodservice
business increased due primarily to the 2004 acquisition of the Veryfine beverage business. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $354&nbsp;million (4.8%), due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($219&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), favorable currency
($172&nbsp;million), higher pricing, net of higher promotional spending ($25&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing in late 2004), and the impact of acquisitions ($7&nbsp;million),
partially offset by the impact of divestitures ($67&nbsp;million). Canada net revenues increased, due primarily to favorable currency and the impact of cheese and coffee pricing, partially offset by
increased promotional spending and lower volume. Cheese net revenues also increased, reflecting commodity-driven pricing from 2004, partially offset by increased promotional spending and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>35</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=36,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=18296,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DK1135A.;21',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1135_1_36"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>the
divestiture of the yogurt assets. In foodservice, net revenues increased, due primarily to favorable currency and the impact of the 2004 Veryfine acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $29&nbsp;million (2.9%), due primarily to higher pricing and favorable costs ($78&nbsp;million, net of higher promotional spending), favorable
volume/mix ($68&nbsp;million including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week) and favorable currency ($31&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher marketing, administration and research
costs ($72&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs, as well as costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), the impact of higher asset impairment and exit costs ($35&nbsp;million),
higher fixed manufacturing costs ($28&nbsp;million) and higher implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($12&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Convenient Meals.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 2.8% including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of shipments
(approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of growth), due primarily to higher shipments in meats, pizza and meals. Meats volume increased, aided by higher shipments of cold cuts and new product
introductions. Meals volume increased, due primarily to the impact of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week, partially offset by the discontinuation of a product line. In pizza, volume also increased due
primarily to the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week and new product introductions, partially offset by competitive activity. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $247&nbsp;million (5.8%), due to higher volume/mix ($227&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>week) and higher pricing, net of
increased promotional spending ($20&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing in meats and pizza). Meats net revenues increased, due primarily to higher volume and commodity-driven price
increases, partially offset by higher promotional spending. Pizza net revenues increased, driven by positive mix from new products and the impact of commodity-driven price increases. In meals, net
revenues increased due primarily to improved mix from new products, partially offset by the discontinuation of a product line and increased promotional spending. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $30&nbsp;million (3.9%), due primarily to higher marketing, administration and research costs ($77&nbsp;million, including higher marketing and
benefit costs, as well as costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week) and higher fixed manufacturing expenses ($30&nbsp;million), partially offset by favorable volume/mix ($45&nbsp;million
including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), lower pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($29&nbsp;million) and higher pricing net of higher costs
($8&nbsp;million, due primarily to higher commodity driven pricing). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Grocery.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 1.1% due to the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of shipments (approximately
2&nbsp;percentage points of growth). Enhancers volume increased slightly due primarily to higher shipments of spoonable dressings, partially offset by lower volume in pourable dressings and barbecue
sauce due to increased competitive activity. In desserts, volume increased aided by new product introductions in refrigerated ready-to-eat desserts, partially offset by
declines in dry packaged desserts and the impact of the fruit snacks divestiture. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues decreased $4&nbsp;million (0.2%), due primarily to the impact of divestitures ($30&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher volume/mix ($20&nbsp;million, including
the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week) and higher pricing, net of increased promotional spending ($5&nbsp;million). Desserts net revenues decreased, due primarily to the impact of the fruit
snacks divestiture and declines in dry packaged desserts, partially offset by new product introductions in refrigerated ready-to-eat desserts and gains in marshmallows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $151&nbsp;million (16.9%), due primarily to higher pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($91&nbsp;million),
unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($31&nbsp;million, due primarily to higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending), higher marketing, administration and research costs
($21&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs, as well as costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week) and higher fixed manufacturing costs ($10&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Snacks&nbsp;&amp; Cereals.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 3.5% including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of
shipments (approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of growth), as gains in biscuits and cereals were partially offset by a decline in salted snacks. In biscuits, volume increased due primarily to new
product introductions in </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>36</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=37,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=805352,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DK1135A.;21',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1135_1_37"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>cookies.
Cereals volume increased due primarily to new product introductions and expanded distribution in ready-to-eat cereals. In salted snacks, volume declined due to higher
commodity-driven pricing on snack nuts and increased competitive activity. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $339&nbsp;million (6.3%), due primarily to higher volume/mix ($296&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week) and higher pricing, net
of increased promotional spending ($39&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing in snack nuts and cereals). Biscuits net revenues increased, driven by new product introductions and improved
mix. Cereals net revenues also increased, due primarily to new product introductions and higher shipments and pricing of ready-to-eat cereals. Salted snacks net revenues
increased, as lower volume was offset by higher prices. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $134&nbsp;million (18.2%), due primarily to higher volume/mix ($171&nbsp;million including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week) and lower
pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($153&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher marketing, administration and research costs ($96&nbsp;million, including higher
marketing and benefit costs, as well as costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($72&nbsp;million, due primarily to higher commodity costs and
increased promotional spending), higher fixed manufacturing costs ($15&nbsp;million) and the net impact of higher implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($6&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2004 compared with 2003  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares Kraft North America Commercial's operating results for 2004 with 2003. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume
increased 4.3%, due primarily to an acquisition in the U.S. Beverages segment and increased shipments in the U.S. Cheese, Canada&nbsp;&amp; North America Foodservice segment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $1,123&nbsp;million (5.4%), due primarily to higher volume/mix ($537&nbsp;million), higher net pricing ($312&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven price
increases, partially offset by increased promotional spending), favorable currency ($164&nbsp;million) and the impact of acquisitions ($117&nbsp;million). Higher net revenues were driven by
cheese, meats and nuts due to higher volume in
response to consumer nutrition trends and higher commodity-driven pricing net of increased promotional spending. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $788&nbsp;million (16.9%), due primarily to the 2004 pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($391&nbsp;million),
unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($356&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending), higher marketing, administration and research costs
($214&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs) and the 2004 implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($40&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher volume/mix
($197&nbsp;million) and favorable currency ($29&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following discusses operating results within each of Kraft North America Commercial's reportable segments. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Beverages.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 12.7%, due primarily to the 2004 acquisition of a beverage business
and new product introductions in refreshment beverages. In coffee, volume also increased, due to product quality improvements and the impact of an expanded distribution arrangement. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $122&nbsp;million (5.0%), due primarily to the impact of acquisitions ($94&nbsp;million) and higher volume/mix ($85&nbsp;million), partially offset by
increased promotional spending ($56&nbsp;million). Net revenues increased in refreshment beverages due primarily to the acquisition of Veryfine and increased shipments of sugar-free
powdered beverages. In coffee, increased net revenues were due primarily to favorable mix from higher shipments of premium coffee, partially offset by increased promotional spending in base coffee in
response to competitive activity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $151&nbsp;million (24.0%), due primarily to higher marketing, administration and research costs ($98&nbsp;million), unfavorable costs and higher
promotional spending </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=38,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=1047602,FOLIO='37',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DK1135A.;21',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1135_1_38"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>($85&nbsp;million,
including higher commodity costs), the 2004 pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($9&nbsp;million) and the 2004 implementation costs associated with
the restructuring program ($4&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher volume/mix ($49&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Cheese, Canada&nbsp;&amp; North America Foodservice.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 3.5%, due primarily to
higher volume in foodservice and cheese. Volume in the foodservice business increased, due primarily to an acquisition of a beverage business in 2004 and higher shipments to national accounts. Cheese
volume also increased, benefiting from increased promotional spending. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $704&nbsp;million (10.5%), due primarily to higher volume/mix ($272&nbsp;million), higher pricing, net of higher promotional reinvestment spending in cheese
($248&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing), favorable currency ($164&nbsp;million) and the impact of acquisitions.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cheese revenues increased due primarily to increased
shipments and commodity-driven pricing, partially offset by increased promotional spending. In Canada, net revenues also increased due to cheese pricing. Foodservice net revenues increased, due
primarily to commodity-driven net pricing in cheese and meat, and higher shipments. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $282&nbsp;million (22.2%), due primarily to unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($214&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs and
increased promotional spending), the 2004 pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($111&nbsp;million), higher fixed manufacturing costs ($50&nbsp;million, including higher
benefit costs), higher marketing, administration and research costs ($26&nbsp;million) and the 2004 implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($8&nbsp;million), partially
offset by higher volume/mix ($99&nbsp;million) and favorable currency ($29&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Convenient Meals.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 1.6%, due primarily to gains in meats and pizza, partially
offset by lower shipments in meals. Meats volume increased driven by higher consumption of cold cuts, supported by higher investment spending. Pizza volume also increased, aided by new product
introductions. In meals, volume declined due to the discontinuation of certain product lines in the second half of 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $192&nbsp;million (4.7%), due primarily to higher volume/mix ($114&nbsp;million), higher pricing ($75&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing in
meats and pizza) and the impact of acquisitions. Meats net revenues increased due primarily to higher shipments of cold cuts, bacon and hot dogs, and commodity-driven pricing. In pizza, net revenues
were higher due to new product introductions and commodity-driven pricing actions. Meals net revenues increased slightly as the impact of higher shipments of dinners was partially offset by the
discontinuation of a product line. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $46&nbsp;million (5.6%), due primarily to the 2004 pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($41&nbsp;million), higher
marketing, administration and research costs ($38&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs), the impact of acquisitions ($5&nbsp;million) and the 2004 implementation costs associated with the
restructuring program ($4&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher volume/mix ($40&nbsp;million) and higher pricing, net of unfavorable costs ($7&nbsp;million, including higher commodity
costs). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Grocery.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 0.7%, due primarily to gains in enhancers, partially offset by a
decline in desserts. Volume increased in enhancers, due primarily to mayonnaise and salad dressings. In desserts, volume declined, due primarily to lower shipments of fruit snacks, partially offset by
higher shipments in frozen toppings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $37&nbsp;million (1.5%), due primarily to higher pricing and lower promotional spending ($34&nbsp;million) and higher volume/mix. In enhancers, net revenues
increased due primarily to higher shipments of pourable and spoonable salad dressings. Desserts net revenues increased due primarily to lower promotional spending for new product introductions and
favorable mix from sugar-free desserts. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=39,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=730991,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DK1135A.;21',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1135_1_39"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income was equal to the prior year, as lower fixed manufacturing costs ($17&nbsp;million) and higher volume/mix ($10&nbsp;million) were offset by the 2004
pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($8&nbsp;million), the 2004 implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($6&nbsp;million), higher marketing,
administration and research costs ($5&nbsp;million) and unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. Snacks&nbsp;&amp; Cereals.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 1.5%, as higher salted snacks and biscuits volume was
partially offset by a decline in cereals. Salted snacks volume increased due to consumer nutrition trends and marketing programs in nuts. In biscuits, volume increased, driven by new product
introductions. In cereals, volume declined due to low carbohydrate diet trends, which impacted the category, and increased competitive activity. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $68&nbsp;million (1.3%), due primarily to higher volume/mix ($62&nbsp;million) and higher pricing ($11&nbsp;million, including the absence of high product
returns associated with new products incurred in 2003, partially offset by increased promotional spending). In snacks, higher net revenues were due primarily to increased shipments of snack nuts due
to consumer nutrition trends. Biscuit net revenues were higher due to the impact of lower product returns, partially offset by higher promotional spending. Cereals net revenues decreased due to lower
shipments caused by consumer nutrition trends and increased competitive activity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $309&nbsp;million (29.5%), due primarily to the 2004 pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($222&nbsp;million),
unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($62&nbsp;million, due to higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending), higher marketing, administration and research costs
($47&nbsp;million) and the 2004 implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($18&nbsp;million), partially offset by lower fixed manufacturing costs ($40&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Kraft International Commercial  </I></B></FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2005 compared with 2004  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares Kraft International Commercial's operating results for 2005 with 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume
decreased 1.2% including the benefit of 53 weeks in 2005 results. Excluding the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of shipments in 2005 and the impact of divestitures, volume decreased
approximately 2%, due primarily to the effect of commodity-driven pricing. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=10,SEQ=40,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=920218,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DK1135A.;21',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1135_1_40"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $712&nbsp;million (7.0%), due primarily to favorable currency ($361&nbsp;million), higher pricing, net of increased promotional spending ($214&nbsp;million,
including commodity-driven pricing) and favorable volume/mix ($213&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), partially offset by the impact of divestitures
($77&nbsp;million). Net revenues were up 14% in developing markets, driven by significant growth in Russia, Ukraine and the Middle East. In addition, net revenues increased in several Western
European markets, partially offset by a decline in volume, particularly in Germany. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $189&nbsp;million (20.3%), due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($115&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), net
gains on the sale of businesses ($112&nbsp;million), lower pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($68&nbsp;million), favorable currency ($59&nbsp;million) and a 2004
equity investment impairment charge related to a joint venture in Turkey ($47&nbsp;million), partially offset by unfavorable costs and increased promotional spending, net of higher pricing
($99&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs), higher marketing, administration and research costs ($53&nbsp;million, including higher marketing and benefit costs, and costs associated with
the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week, partially offset by a $16&nbsp;million recovery of receivables previously written off), the impact of divestitures ($24&nbsp;million), the net impact of higher
implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($22&nbsp;million) and higher fixed manufacturing costs ($16&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following discusses operating results within each of Kraft International Commercial's reportable segments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Europe, Middle East&nbsp;&amp; Africa.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 1.8% including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of
shipments (approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of growth), due primarily to lower volume in Germany and the divestiture of the U.K. desserts assets in the first quarter of 2005, partially offset
by growth in developing markets, including Russia, Ukraine and the Middle East. In grocery, volume declined, due to the divestiture of the U.K. desserts assets in the first quarter of 2005 and lower
results in Egypt and Germany. Beverages volume declined, driven by lower coffee shipments in Germany, due to commodity-driven price increases, partially offset by higher refreshment beverage shipments
in the Middle East and higher coffee shipments in Russia and Ukraine. Convenient meals volume declined, due primarily to lower category performance in the U.K. and lower promotions in Germany. Cheese
volume increased due to higher shipments in the U.K., Italy and the Middle East. In snacks, volume increased, as gains in confectionery, benefiting from growth in Russia and Ukraine, were partially
offset by lower biscuits volume in Egypt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $477&nbsp;million (6.3%), due primarily to favorable currency ($235&nbsp;million), favorable volume/mix ($171&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the
53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), higher pricing, net of increased promotional spending ($131&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing in coffee), partially offset by the impact of divestitures
($60&nbsp;million). Significant growth in Russia and Ukraine was partially offset by a decline in Germany. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $115&nbsp;million (16.8%), due primarily to net gains on the sale of businesses ($108&nbsp;million), favorable volume/mix ($87&nbsp;million
including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), lower pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($53&nbsp;million), a 2004 equity investment impairment charge related to
a joint venture in Turkey ($47&nbsp;million) and favorable currency ($32&nbsp;million), partially offset by unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($144&nbsp;million, due primarily to higher
commodity costs and increased promotional spending), higher marketing, administration and research costs ($30&nbsp;million, including costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), the impact
of divestitures ($25&nbsp;million) and the net impact of higher implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($17&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Latin America&nbsp;&amp; Asia Pacific.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 0.4% including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of
shipments (approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of growth), due primarily to lower shipments in China, partially offset by growth in Southeast Asia. Grocery volume declined, due primarily to lower
shipments in Brazil and Central America. Snacks volume also declined, impacted by increased biscuit competition in China and resizing of biscuit products in Latin America, partially offset by higher
shipments in Venezuela. In </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=11,SEQ=41,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=295505,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DK1135A.;21',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1135_1_41"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>beverages,
volume increased, due primarily to refreshment beverage gains in the Philippines, Argentina and Puerto Rico. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $235&nbsp;million (9.1%), due primarily to favorable currency ($126&nbsp;million), higher pricing, net of increased promotional spending ($83&nbsp;million)
and favorable volume/mix ($42&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>week), partially offset by the impact of divestitures ($17&nbsp;million). Net revenues increased in
several geographies, including volume and pricing gains in Venezuela, and increased refreshment beverage and cheese shipments in the Philippines. Net revenues declined in China, where the Company
faced increased competitive activity in biscuits. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $74&nbsp;million (29.6%), due primarily to higher pricing net of unfavorable costs ($45&nbsp;million, including increased promotional spending),
favorable volume/mix ($28&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), favorable currency ($27&nbsp;million) and lower pre-tax charges for asset impairment and
exit costs ($15&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher marketing, administration and research costs ($23&nbsp;million, including costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week, partially
offset by a $16&nbsp;million recovery of receivables previously written off) and higher fixed manufacturing costs ($18&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2004 compared with 2003  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares Kraft International Commercial's operating results for 2004 with 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume
decreased 1.1%, due primarily to the impact of the divestiture of a rice business and a branded fresh cheese business in Europe in 2003, as well as price competition and trade
inventory reductions in several markets, partially offset by the impact of acquisitions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $547&nbsp;million (5.7%), due primarily to favorable currency ($674&nbsp;million), the impact of acquisitions ($23&nbsp;million) and favorable volume/mix
($23&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of divestitures ($126&nbsp;million) and increased promotional spending, net of higher pricing
($47&nbsp;million). Lower pricing and higher promotional spending on coffee in Europe and lower shipments of refreshment beverages in Mexico negatively impacted net revenues. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $460&nbsp;million (33.0%), due primarily to the pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($206&nbsp;million), unfavorable
costs and increased promotional spending, net of higher pricing ($113&nbsp;million), higher marketing, administration and research costs ($92&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs and
infrastructure investment in developing markets), the 2004 equity investment impairment charge related to a joint venture in Turkey ($47&nbsp;million), the unfavorable net impact related to gains
and losses on the sales of businesses ($34&nbsp;million), the impact of divestitures ($18&nbsp;million) and the 2004 implementation costs associated with the restructuring program
($10&nbsp;million), partially offset by favorable currency ($69&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=12,SEQ=42,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=147484,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DK1135A.;21',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dm1135_1_42"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discusses operating results within each of Kraft International Commercial's reportable segments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Europe, Middle East&nbsp;&amp; Africa.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 1.3%, due primarily to the divestiture of a
rice business and a branded fresh cheese business in Europe in 2003, price competition in France and trade inventory reductions in Russia, partially offset by the impact of acquisitions and volume
growth in Germany, Austria, Italy and Romania. Cheese volume declined, impacted by the divestiture of a branded fresh cheese business in Europe in 2003, partially offset by increased cream cheese
shipments in Germany, Italy and the United Kingdom, and higher process cheese shipments in the United Kingdom. Beverages volume also declined, driven by price competition in coffee in France and lower
shipments of refreshment beverages in the Middle East. Convenient meals volume declined, impacted by the divestiture of a rice business in Europe in 2003. In grocery, volume declined across several
markets, including Germany and Italy, partially offset by increased volume in Egypt, due to an acquisition. Snacks volume increased, as gains in biscuits, benefiting from acquisitions, and new
confectionery product introductions across the segment, were partially offset by trade inventory reductions in Russia. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $508&nbsp;million (7.2%), due primarily to favorable currency ($649&nbsp;million), favorable volume/mix ($48&nbsp;million) and the impact of acquisitions
($21&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of divestitures ($115&nbsp;million) and lower pricing and increased promotional spending ($95&nbsp;million). In cheese, net revenues decreased
primarily due to the divestiture of certain fresh cheese brands in Italy, partially offset by increased shipments of cream cheese and process cheese in Europe. Snacks net revenues increased due to a
salted snacks acquisition in Turkey, a biscuits acquisition in Egypt and higher confectionery shipments in Germany. In beverages, net revenues declined due to coffee price reductions in France and
higher promotional spending in the United Kingdom, France and Germany, partially offset by higher shipments in Ukraine and Romania. Convenient meals net revenues declined due to lower shipments in
Western Europe. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $319&nbsp;million (31.8%), due primarily to the pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($174&nbsp;million), lower
pricing and increased promotional spending ($92&nbsp;million), higher marketing, administration and research costs ($49&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs as well as infrastructure
investment in developing markets), the equity investment impairment charge related to a joint venture in Turkey ($47&nbsp;million), lower gains on the sales of businesses ($26&nbsp;million), the
impact of divestitures ($17&nbsp;million) and the 2004 implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($9&nbsp;million), partially offset by favorable currency ($78&nbsp;million)
and favorable volume/mix ($15&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Latin America&nbsp;&amp; Asia Pacific.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 1.0%, due primarily to lower shipments in
Mexico, Peru and Venezuela, partially offset by growth in Brazil and China. Snacks volume declined, impacted by price competition and trade inventory reductions in Venezuela and Peru. In grocery,
volume declined across several markets, including Peru, Australia and the Philippines. Cheese volume increased, due primarily to gains across several markets, including Japan, Australia and the
Philippines. Beverages volume also increased, due primarily to gains in Brazil and China, partially offset by increased competitive activity in Mexico. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $39&nbsp;million (1.5%), due primarily to higher pricing ($48&nbsp;million, reflecting devaluation-driven cost increases, net of increased promotional
spending) and favorable currency ($25&nbsp;million), partially offset by lower volume/mix ($25&nbsp;million) and the impact of divestitures ($11&nbsp;million). Cheese net revenues increased due
to higher shipments and price increases across Latin America, Southeast Asia and Australia. In snacks, net revenues decreased due to the divestiture of a snack nuts business in Brazil. Beverage net
revenues declined due primarily to lower shipments in Mexico as a result of increased price competition from carbonated beverages. In grocery, net revenues increased due primarily to higher shipments
in Venezuela. Convenient meals net revenues increased due to higher shipments to Puerto Rico. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $141&nbsp;million (36.1%), due primarily to higher marketing, administration and research costs ($43&nbsp;million), the 2004 pre-tax
charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($32&nbsp;million), lower volume/mix ($25&nbsp;million), unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($21&nbsp;million, including increased promotional
spending), unfavorable currency ($9&nbsp;million) and the 2004 pre-tax loss on the sale of a snack nuts business in Brazil ($8&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Financial Review  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Net Cash Provided by Operating Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash provided by operating activities was $3.5&nbsp;billion in 2005, $4.0&nbsp;billion in 2004 and $4.1&nbsp;billion in 2003. The decrease in 2005
operating cash flows from 2004 was due primarily to an increase in income tax payments (primarily related to the sale of the sugar confectionery business), an increase in the use of cash to fund
working capital, due primarily to an increase in cash payments associated with the restructuring plan, and lower earnings, partially offset by lower pension plan
contributions. The decrease in 2004 operating cash flows from 2003 was due primarily to lower net earnings, cash payments associated with the restructuring program and higher pension contributions,
partially offset by a lower use of cash to fund working capital. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Net Cash Provided by (Used in) Investing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;One element of the growth strategy of the Company is to strengthen its brand portfolios through disciplined programs of selective acquisitions and divestitures.
The Company is constantly reviewing potential acquisition candidates and from time to time sells businesses to accelerate the shift in its portfolio toward businesses&#151;whether global,
regional or local&#151;that offer the Company a sustainable competitive advantage. The impact of future acquisitions or divestitures could have a material impact on the Company's cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2005, net cash provided by investing activities was $525&nbsp;million, compared with net cash used in investing activities of $1.1&nbsp;billion and $1.0&nbsp;billion in 2004
and 2003, respectively. The cash provided by investing activities in 2005 includes the proceeds from sales of businesses, including the sugar confectionery business, fruit snacks assets, U.K. desserts
assets, U.S. yogurt assets, a small business in Colombia, a small equity investment in Turkey and a minor trademark in Mexico. The increase in 2004 primarily reflected higher uses of cash for the
purchase of businesses and the reduction of cash received from the sales of businesses, partially offset by lower capital expenditures. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Capital
expenditures, which were funded by operating activities, were $1.2&nbsp;billion, $1.0&nbsp;billion and $1.1&nbsp;billion in 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively. The 2005
capital expenditures were primarily to modernize manufacturing facilities, implement the restructuring program, and support new product and productivity initiatives. In 2006, capital expenditures are
currently expected to be flat to 2005 expenditures, including capital expenditures required for the restructuring program. These expenditures are expected to be funded from operations. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Net Cash Used in Financing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2005, net cash of $4.0&nbsp;billion was used in financing activities, compared with $3.2&nbsp;billion during 2004. The increase in cash used in 2005
was due primarily to an increase in the Company's Class&nbsp;A share repurchases and the repayment of debt, partially offset by an increase in amounts due to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and
affiliates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2004, net cash of $3.2&nbsp;billion was used in financing activities, compared with $2.8&nbsp;billion during 2003. The increase in cash used in 2004 was due primarily to an
increase in the Company's Class&nbsp;A share repurchases and dividend payments. In November&nbsp;2004, the Company issued </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=44,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=953618,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DM1135A.;12',USER='MBLOUNT',CD=';9-MAR-2006;12:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1135_1_44"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>$750&nbsp;million
in third-party long-term debt, the net proceeds of which were used to refinance maturing debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Debt and Liquidity  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Debt.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's total debt, including amounts due to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and affiliates, was $11.2&nbsp;billion
at December&nbsp;31, 2005 and $12.5&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2004. The Company's debt-to-equity ratio was 0.38 at December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 0.42 at
December&nbsp;31, 2004. The Company's debt-to-capitalization ratio was 0.27 at December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 0.30 at December&nbsp;31, 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
November&nbsp;2004, the Company issued $750&nbsp;million of 5-year notes bearing interest at 4.125%. The net proceeds of the offering were used to refinance maturing
debt. The Company has a Form&nbsp;S-3 shelf registration statement on file with the Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC") under which the Company may sell debt securities and/or
warrants to purchase debt securities in one or more offerings up to a total amount of $4.0&nbsp;billion. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company had $3.5&nbsp;billion of capacity remaining under
its shelf registration. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, the Company had short-term amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and affiliates of $652&nbsp;million and $227&nbsp;million,
respectively. The amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. generally include accrued dividends, taxes and service fees. Interest on intercompany borrowings is based on the applicable London
Interbank Offered Rate. The Company had no long-term amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and affiliates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Credit Ratings.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Following a $10.1&nbsp;billion judgment on March&nbsp;21, 2003, against Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s
domestic tobacco subsidiary, Philip Morris USA&nbsp;Inc., the three major credit rating agencies took a series of ratings actions resulting in the lowering of the Company's short-term
and long-term debt ratings, despite the fact the Company is neither a party to, nor has exposure to, this litigation. The Company's credit ratings by Moody's at December&nbsp;31, 2005,
were "P-2" for short-term debt and "A3" for long-term debt, with stable outlook. The Company's credit ratings by Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's at December&nbsp;31,
2005 were "A-2" for short-term debt and "BBB+" for long-term
debt, with stable outlook. The Company's credit ratings by Fitch Rating Services at December&nbsp;31, 2005 were "F-2" for short-term debt and "BBB+" for long-term
debt, with stable outlook. As a result of the rating agencies' actions, borrowing costs have increased. None of the Company's debt agreements requires accelerated repayment in the event of a decrease
in credit ratings. The credit rating downgrades by Moody's, Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and Fitch Rating Services had no impact on any of the Company's other existing third-party contracts. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Credit Lines.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company maintains revolving credit facilities that have historically been used to support the issuance of
commercial paper. In April&nbsp;2005, the Company terminated its $2.0&nbsp;billion, multi-year revolving credit facility expiring in July&nbsp;2006 and its $2.5&nbsp;billion,
364-day revolving credit facility expiring in July&nbsp;2005 and replaced them with a new $4.5&nbsp;billion, multi-year revolving credit facility that expires in
April&nbsp;2010. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the credit line for the Company and the related activity were as follows (in billions of dollars): </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's revolving credit facility, which is for its sole use, requires the maintenance of a minimum net worth of $20.0&nbsp;billion. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company's
net worth was $29.6&nbsp;billion. The Company expects to continue to meet this covenant. The revolving credit facility does not include any other financial tests, any credit rating triggers or any
provisions that could require the posting of collateral. The Company expects to refinance long-term and short-term debt from time to time. The </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=45,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=840439,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DM1135A.;12',USER='MBLOUNT',CD=';9-MAR-2006;12:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1135_1_45"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>nature
and amount of the Company's long-term and short-term debt and the proportionate amount of each can be expected to vary as a result of future business requirements,
market conditions and other factors. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to the above, certain international subsidiaries of Kraft maintain uncommitted credit lines to meet the short-term working capital needs of the international
businesses. These credit lines, which amounted to approximately $1.3&nbsp;billion as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, are for the sole use of the Company's international businesses. Borrowings on these
lines amounted to approximately $400&nbsp;million and $150&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements and Aggregate Contractual Obligations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has no off-balance sheet arrangements other than the guarantees and contractual obligations that are discussed below. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Guarantees.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note&nbsp;18 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company had third-party guarantees,
which are primarily derived from acquisition and divestiture activities, of approximately $27&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2005. Substantially all of these guarantees expire through 2013,
with $14&nbsp;million expiring during 2006. The Company is required to perform under these guarantees in the event that a third party fails to make contractual payments or achieve performance
measures. The Company has a liability of $17&nbsp;million on its consolidated balance sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2005, relating to these guarantees. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, at December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company was contingently liable for $127&nbsp;million of guarantees related to its own performance. These include surety bonds related to
dairy commodity purchases and guarantees related to the payment of customs duties and taxes, and letters of credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Guarantees
do not have, and are not expected to have, a significant impact on the Company's liquidity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aggregate Contractual Obligations.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table summarizes the Company's contractual obligations at
December&nbsp;31, 2005: </FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Amounts
represent the expected cash payments of the Company's long-term debt and do not include bond premiums or discounts, and interest.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Operating
leases represent the minimum rental commitments under non-cancelable operating leases. The Company has no significant capital lease obligations.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Purchase
obligations for inventory and production costs (such as raw materials, indirect materials and supplies, packaging, co-manufacturing arrangements, storage and
distribution) are </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=46,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=36920,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DM1135A.;12',USER='MBLOUNT',CD=';9-MAR-2006;12:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1135_1_46"> </A>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>commitments
for projected needs to be utilized in the normal course of business. Other purchase obligations include commitments for marketing, advertising, capital expenditures, information technology
and professional services. Arrangements are considered purchase obligations if a contract specifies all significant terms, including fixed or minimum quantities to be purchased, a pricing structure
and approximate timing of the transaction. Most arrangements are cancelable without a significant penalty, and with short notice (usually 30&nbsp;days). Any amounts reflected on the consolidated
balance sheet as accounts payable and accrued liabilities are excluded from the table above. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(4)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Other
long-term liabilities primarily consist of certain specific severance and incentive compensation arrangements. The following long-term liabilities
included on the consolidated balance sheet are excluded from the table above: accrued pension, postretirement health care and postemployment costs, income taxes, minority interest, insurance accruals
and other accruals. The Company is unable to estimate the timing of the payments for these items. Currently, the Company anticipates making U.S. pension contributions of approximately
$140&nbsp;million in 2006 and non-U.S. pension contributions of approximately $106&nbsp;million in 2006, based on current tax law (as discussed in Note&nbsp;15 to the consolidated
financial statements). </FONT></DD></DL>
<BR>
<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="CENTER" WIDTH="120">

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company believes that its cash from operations and existing credit facility will provide sufficient liquidity to meet its working capital needs (including the cash requirements of
the restructuring program), planned capital expenditures, future contractual obligations and payment of its anticipated quarterly dividends. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Equity and Dividends  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2003, the Company's Board of Directors approved the repurchase from time to time of up to $700&nbsp;million of the Company's Class&nbsp;A
common stock. In December&nbsp;2004, the Company completed the program, acquiring 21.7&nbsp;million Class&nbsp;A shares at an average price of $32.23 per share. In December&nbsp;2004, the
Company commenced repurchasing shares under a two-year $1.5&nbsp;billion Class&nbsp;A common stock repurchase program authorized by its Board of Directors. Through December&nbsp;31,
2005, repurchases under the $1.5&nbsp;billion program were 40.6&nbsp;million shares at a cost of $1.25&nbsp;billion, or $30.81 per share. During 2005, the Company repurchased 39.2&nbsp;million
shares at a cost of $1.2&nbsp;billion, and in 2004, the Company repurchased 21.5&nbsp;million shares at a cost of $700&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
March&nbsp;2006, the Company's Board of Directors authorized a new share repurchase program to repurchase from time to time up to $2.0&nbsp;billion of the Company's Class&nbsp;A
common stock. This new program, expected to run through 2008, will commence upon the completion of the existing two-year $1.5&nbsp;billion program, which is expected to be completed
during the first quarter of 2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed in Note&nbsp;11 to the consolidated financial statements, during 2005 and 2004, the Company granted approximately 4.2&nbsp;million and 4.1&nbsp;million restricted
Class&nbsp;A shares, respectively, to eligible U.S.-based employees, and during 2005 and 2004, also issued to eligible
non-U.S. employees rights to receive approximately 1.8&nbsp;million and 1.9&nbsp;million Class&nbsp;A equivalent shares, respectively. The market value per restricted share or right
was $33.32 and $32.23 on the dates of the 2005 and 2004 grants, respectively. Restrictions on most of the stock and rights granted in 2005 lapse in the first quarter of 2008, while restrictions on
grants in 2004 lapse in the first quarter of 2007. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2004, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (revised 2004), "Share-Based Payment" ("SFAS No.&nbsp;123R"). SFAS No.&nbsp;123R requires companies to measure compensation cost for
share-based payments at fair value. The Company will adopt this new standard prospectively, on January&nbsp;1, 2006, and the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123R will not have a material impact on its
consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the number of shares to be issued upon </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=47,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=463637,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DM1135A.;12',USER='MBLOUNT',CD=';9-MAR-2006;12:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1135_1_47"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>exercise
of outstanding stock options and vesting of non-U.S. rights to receive equivalent shares was 19.9&nbsp;million, or 1.2% of total Class&nbsp;A and Class&nbsp;B shares
outstanding. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Dividends
paid in 2005 and 2004 were $1,437&nbsp;million and $1,280&nbsp;million, respectively, an increase of 12.3%, reflecting a higher dividend rate in 2005, partially offset by a
lower number of shares outstanding as a result of Class&nbsp;A share repurchases. During the third quarter of 2005, the Company's Board of Directors approved a 12.2% increase in the current
quarterly dividend rate to $0.23 per share on its Class&nbsp;A and Class&nbsp;B common stock. As a result, the present annualized dividend rate is $0.92 per common share. The declaration of
dividends is subject to the discretion of the Company's Board of Directors and will depend on various factors, including the Company's net earnings, financial condition, cash requirements, future
prospects and other factors deemed relevant by the Company's Board of Directors. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Market Risk  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company operates globally, with manufacturing and sales facilities in various locations around the world, and utilizes certain financial instruments to manage
its foreign currency and commodity exposures. Derivative financial instruments are used by the Company, principally to reduce exposures to market risks resulting from fluctuations in foreign exchange
rates and commodity prices by creating offsetting exposures. The Company is not a party to leveraged derivatives and, by policy, does not use financial instruments for speculative purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, ineffectiveness related to cash flow hedges was not material. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company was hedging
forecasted transactions for periods not exceeding the next fifteen months. The Company estimates that derivative losses of approximately $2&nbsp;million, net of income taxes, reported in accumulated
other comprehensive
earnings (losses) at December&nbsp;31, 2005 will be reclassified to the consolidated statement of earnings within the next twelve months. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Foreign Exchange Rates.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company uses forward foreign exchange contracts and foreign currency options to mitigate its
exposure to changes in exchange rates from third-party and intercompany actual and forecasted transactions. Substantially all of the Company's derivative financial instruments are effective as hedges.
The primary currencies to which the Company is exposed, based on the size and location of its businesses, include the euro, Swiss franc, British pound and Canadian dollar. At December&nbsp;31, 2005
and 2004, the Company had foreign exchange option and forward contracts with aggregate notional amounts of $2.2&nbsp;billion and $2.9&nbsp;billion, respectively. The effective portion of
unrealized gains and losses associated with forward and option contracts is deferred as a component of accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) until the underlying hedged transactions are
reported on the Company's consolidated statement of earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commodities.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is exposed to price risk related to forecasted purchases of certain commodities used as raw
materials by its businesses. Accordingly, the Company uses commodity forward contracts as cash flow hedges, primarily for coffee and cocoa. Commodity futures and options are also used to hedge the
price of certain commodities, including milk, coffee, cocoa, wheat, corn, sugar and soybean oil. In general, commodity forward contracts qualify for the normal purchase exception under SFAS
No.&nbsp;133 and are, therefore, not subject to the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;133. At December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, the Company had net long commodity positions of $521&nbsp;million and
$443&nbsp;million, respectively. Unrealized gains or losses on net commodity positions were immaterial at December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004. The effective portion of unrealized gains and losses on
commodity futures and option contracts is deferred as a component of accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) and is recognized as a component of cost of sales in the Company's consolidated
statement of earnings when the related inventory is sold. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=48,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=759631,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DM1135A.;12',USER='MBLOUNT',CD=';9-MAR-2006;12:42' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1135_1_48"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Value at Risk.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company uses a value at risk ("VAR") computation to estimate the potential one-day loss in the
fair value of its interest rate-sensitive financial instruments and to estimate the potential one-day loss in pre-tax earnings of its foreign currency and commodity
price-sensitive derivative financial instruments. The VAR computation includes the Company's debt; short-term investments; foreign currency forwards, swaps and options; and commodity
futures, forwards and options. Anticipated transactions, foreign currency trade payables and receivables, and net investments in foreign subsidiaries, which the foregoing instruments are intended to
hedge, were excluded from the computation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
VAR estimates were made assuming normal market conditions, using a 95% confidence interval. The Company used a "variance/co-variance" model to determine the observed
interrelationships between movements in interest rates and various currencies. These
interrelationships were determined by observing interest rate and forward currency rate movements over the preceding quarter for the calculation of VAR amounts at December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004,
and over each of the four preceding quarters for the calculation of average VAR amounts during each year. The values of foreign currency and commodity options do not change on a
one-to-one basis with the underlying currency or commodity, and were valued accordingly in the VAR computation. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
estimated potential one-day loss in fair value of the Company's interest rate-sensitive instruments, primarily debt, under normal market conditions and the
estimated potential one-day loss in pre-tax earnings from foreign currency and commodity instruments under normal market conditions, as calculated in the VAR model, were as
follows (in millions): </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=11 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Pre-Tax Earnings Impact</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>

</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This
VAR computation is a risk analysis tool designed to statistically estimate the maximum probable daily loss from adverse movements in interest rates, foreign currency
rates and commodity prices under normal market conditions. The computation does not purport to represent actual losses in fair value or earnings to be incurred by the Company, nor does it consider the
effect of favorable changes in market rates. The Company cannot predict actual future movements in such market rates and does not present these VAR results to be indicative of future movements in such
market rates or to be representative of any actual impact that future changes in market rates may have on its future results of operations or financial position. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>New Accounting Standards  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Note&nbsp;2 to the consolidated financial statements for a discussion of new accounting standards. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Contingencies  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Note&nbsp;18 to the consolidated financial statements for a discussion of contingencies. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dm1135_item_7a._quantitative_and_qual__ite02650"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm1135_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 7A.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk.    <BR>    </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See paragraphs captioned "Market Risk" and "Value at Risk" in Item 7 above. </FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=49,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=757629,FOLIO='48',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]DM1135A.;12',USER='MBLOUNT',CD=';9-MAR-2006;12:42' -->
