<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>79</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=80,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=632844,FOLIO='79',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]EA1135A.;8',USER='FLANGST',CD=';9-MAR-2006;02:25' -->
<A NAME="page_ea1135_1_80"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The accumulated benefit obligation, which represents benefits earned to date, for the U.S. pension plans was $5,580&nbsp;million and $5,327&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively. The accumulated benefit obligation for the non-U.S. pension plans was $3,494&nbsp;million and $3,251&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, certain of the Company's U.S. pension plans were underfunded, with projected benefit obligations, accumulated benefit obligations and the fair value
of plan assets of $268&nbsp;million, $211&nbsp;million and $14&nbsp;million, respectively, in 2005, and $260&nbsp;million, $188&nbsp;million and $11&nbsp;million, respectively, in 2004.
The majority of these relate to plans for salaried employees that cannot be funded under IRS regulations. For certain non-U.S. plans, which have accumulated benefit obligations in excess
of plan assets, the projected benefit obligation, accumulated benefit obligation and fair value of plan assets were $2,134&nbsp;million, $1,993&nbsp;million and $1,088&nbsp;million,
respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, and $2,012&nbsp;million, $1,877&nbsp;million and $950&nbsp;million, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2004. </FONT></P>

following weighted-average assumptions were used to determine the Company's benefit obligations under the plans at December&nbsp;31: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's 2005&nbsp;year end U.S. and Canadian plans discount rates were developed from a model portfolio of high quality, fixed-income debt instruments
with durations that match the expected future cash flows of the benefit obligations. The 2005&nbsp;year end discount rates for the Company's non-U.S. plans were developed from local bond
indices that match local benefit obligations as closely as possible. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2005, employees left the Company under workforce reduction programs, resulting in settlement losses of $10&nbsp;million for the U.S. plans. In addition,
retiring employees elected lump-sum payments, resulting in settlement losses of $73&nbsp;million, $41&nbsp;million and $51&nbsp;million in 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.
Non-U.S. plant closures and early retirement benefits resulted in curtailment and settlement losses of $25&nbsp;million and $7&nbsp;million in 2005 and 2004, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>80</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's expected rate of return on plan assets is determined by the plan assets' historical long-term investment performance, current asset allocation and estimates of
future long-term returns by asset class. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Kraft
and certain of its subsidiaries sponsor employee savings plans, to which the Company contributes. These plans cover certain salaried, non-union and union employees. The
Company's contributions and costs are determined by the matching of employee contributions, as defined by the plans. Amounts charged to expense for defined contribution plans totaled
$94&nbsp;million, $92&nbsp;million and $84&nbsp;million in 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> Plan Assets  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's investment strategy is based on an expectation that equity securities will outperform debt securities over the long term. Accordingly, the
composition of the Company's U.S. plan assets is broadly characterized as a 70%/30% allocation between equity and debt securities. The strategy utilizes indexed U.S. equity securities, actively
managed international equity securities and actively managed investment grade debt securities (which constitute 80% or more of debt securities) with lesser allocations to high yield and international
debt securities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the plans outside the U.S., the investment strategy is subject to local regulations and the asset/liability profiles of the plans in each individual country. These specific
circumstances result in a level of equity exposure that is typically less than the U.S. plans. In aggregate, the actual asset allocations of the non-U.S. plans are virtually identical to
their respective asset policy targets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company attempts to mitigate investment risk by rebalancing between equity and debt asset classes as the Company's contributions and monthly benefit payments are made. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company presently makes, and plans to make, contributions, to the extent that they do not generate an excise tax liability, in order to maintain plan assets in excess of the
accumulated benefit obligation of its funded U.S. and non-U.S. plans. Currently, the Company anticipates making contributions of approximately $140&nbsp;million in 2006 to its U.S. plans
and approximately $106&nbsp;million in 2006 to its non-U.S. plans, based on current tax law. However, these estimates are subject to change as a result of many factors, including changes
in tax and other benefit laws, as well as asset performance significantly above or below the assumed long-term rate of return on pension assets, or significant changes in interest rates. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>81</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=82,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=247223,FOLIO='81',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]EA1135A.;8',USER='FLANGST',CD=';9-MAR-2006;02:25' -->
<A NAME="page_ea1135_1_82"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
estimated future benefit payments from the Company's pension plans at December&nbsp;31, 2005, were as follows: </FONT></P>

<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>U.S.&nbsp;Plans</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Non-U.S.&nbsp;Plans</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2003, the United States enacted into law the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003 (the "Act"). The Act
establishes a prescription drug benefit under Medicare, known as "Medicare Part&nbsp;D," and a federal subsidy to sponsors of retiree health care benefit plans that provide a benefit that is at
least actuarially equivalent to Medicare Part&nbsp;D. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
May&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position No.&nbsp;106-2, "Accounting and Disclosure Requirements Related to the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and
Modernization Act of 2003" ("FSP&nbsp;106-2"). FSP&nbsp;106-2 requires companies to account for the effect of the subsidy on benefits attributable to past service as an
actuarial experience gain and as a reduction of the service cost component of net postretirement health care costs for amounts attributable to current service, if the benefit provided is at least
actuarially equivalent to Medicare Part&nbsp;D. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company adopted FSP&nbsp;106-2 in the third quarter of 2004. The impact for 2005 and 2004 was a reduction of pre-tax net postretirement health care costs
and an increase in net earnings. The amounts in the table above reflect the following benefits: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, as of July&nbsp;1, 2004, the Company reduced its accumulated postretirement benefit obligation for the subsidy related to benefits attributed to
past service by $315&nbsp;million and decreased its unrecognized actuarial losses by the same amount. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2006, the discount rate used to determine the Company's net postretirement cost will be 5.60% for its U.S. plans and 5.00% for its Canadian plans, and the
health care cost trend rate will be 8.00% for its U.S. plans and 9.00% for its Canadian plans. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As previously discussed in Note&nbsp;3. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset Impairment, Exit and Implementation Costs</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, the Company announced
several workforce reduction programs during 2005 and 2004 as part of the overall restructuring program. The cost of these programs, $139&nbsp;million and $167&nbsp;million in 2005 and 2004,
respectively, is included in other expense, above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's postemployment plans are not funded. The changes in the benefit obligations of the plans at December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, were as follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The accumulated benefit obligation was determined using an assumed ultimate annual turnover rate of 0.3% in 2005 and 2004, assumed compensation cost increases of
4.0% in 2005 and 2004, and assumed benefits as defined in the respective plans. Postemployment costs arising from actions that offer employees benefits in excess of those specified in the respective
plans are charged to expense when incurred. </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>996</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="89%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;17.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financial Instruments:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Derivative financial instruments  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company operates globally, with manufacturing and sales facilities in various locations around the world, and utilizes certain financial instruments to manage
its foreign currency and commodity exposures. Derivative financial instruments are used by the Company, principally to reduce exposures to market risks resulting from fluctuations in foreign exchange
rates and commodity prices by creating offsetting exposures. The Company is not a party to leveraged derivatives and, by policy, does not use financial instruments for speculative purposes. Financial
instruments qualifying for hedge accounting must maintain a specified level of effectiveness between the hedging instrument and the item being hedged, both at inception and throughout the hedged
period. The Company formally documents the nature of and relationships between the hedging instruments and hedged items, as well as its risk-management objectives, strategies for
undertaking the various hedge transactions and method of assessing hedge effectiveness. Additionally, for hedges of forecasted transactions, the significant characteristics and expected terms of the
forecasted transaction must be specifically identified, and it must be probable that each forecasted transaction will occur. If it were deemed probable that the forecasted transaction will not occur,
the gain or loss would be recognized in earnings currently. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company uses forward foreign exchange contracts and foreign currency options to mitigate its exposure to changes in exchange rates from third-party and intercompany actual and
forecasted transactions. Substantially all of the Company's derivative financial instruments are effective as hedges. The primary currencies to which the Company is exposed, based on the size and
location of its </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>85</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=86,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=827862,FOLIO='85',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]EC1135A.;7',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_ec1135_1_86"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>businesses,
include the euro, Swiss franc, British pound and Canadian dollar. At December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, the Company had foreign exchange option and forward contracts with aggregate
notional amounts of $2.2&nbsp;billion and $2.9&nbsp;billion, respectively. The effective portion of unrealized gains and losses associated with forward and option contracts is deferred as a
component of accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) until the underlying hedged transactions are reported on the Company's consolidated statement of earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company is exposed to price risk related to forecasted purchases of certain commodities used as raw materials by its businesses. Accordingly, the Company uses commodity forward
contracts as cash flow hedges, primarily for coffee and cocoa. Commodity futures and options are also used to hedge the price of certain commodities, including milk, coffee, cocoa, wheat, corn, sugar
and soybean oil. In general, commodity forward contracts qualify for the normal purchase exception under SFAS No.&nbsp;133 and are, therefore, not subject to the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;133.
At December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, the Company had net long commodity positions of $521&nbsp;million and $443&nbsp;million, respectively. Unrealized gains or losses on net commodity positions
were immaterial at December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004. The effective portion of unrealized gains and losses on commodity futures and option contracts is deferred as a component of accumulated other
comprehensive earnings (losses) and is recognized as a component of cost of sales in the Company's consolidated statement of earnings when the related inventory is sold. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ineffectiveness
related to cash flow hedges was not material for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company was hedging forecasted
transactions for periods not exceeding the next fifteen months. At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company estimates that derivative losses of approximately $2&nbsp;million, net of income taxes,
reported in accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) will be reclassified to the consolidated statement of earnings within the next twelve months. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Derivative
gains or losses reported in accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) are a result of qualifying hedging activity. Transfers of gains or losses from accumulated other
comprehensive earnings (losses) to earnings are offset by corresponding gains or losses on the underlying hedged item. Hedging activity affected accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses), net
of income taxes, during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, as follows (in millions): </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Credit exposure and credit risk  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is exposed to credit loss in the event of nonperformance by counterparties. However, the Company does not anticipate nonperformance, and such exposure
was not material at December&nbsp;31, 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Fair value  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The aggregate fair value, based on market quotes, of the Company's third-party debt at December&nbsp;31, 2005, was $10,750&nbsp;million as compared with its
carrying value of $10,548&nbsp;million. The aggregate fair value of the Company's third-party debt at December&nbsp;31, 2004, was $12,835&nbsp;million as compared with its carrying value of
$12,291&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
Notes&nbsp;4, 8 and 9 for additional disclosures of fair value for short-term borrowings and long-term debt. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>86</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=87,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=674339,FOLIO='86',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]EC1135A.;7',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';7-MAR-2006;14:42' -->
<A NAME="page_ec1135_1_87"> </A>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;18.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Contingencies:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Kraft and its subsidiaries are parties to a variety of legal proceedings arising out of the normal course of business, including a few cases in which substantial
amounts of damages are sought. While the results of litigation cannot be predicted with certainty, management believes that the final outcome of these proceedings will not have a material adverse
effect on the Company's consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Third-Party Guarantees  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company's third-party guarantees, which are primarily derived from acquisition and divestiture activities, approximated
$27&nbsp;million. Substantially all of these guarantees expire through 2013, with $14&nbsp;million expiring during 2006. The Company is required to perform under these guarantees in the event that
a third party fails to make contractual payments or achieve performance measures. The Company has a liability of $17&nbsp;million on its consolidated balance sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2005,
relating to these guarantees. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;19.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Quarterly Financial Data (Unaudited):  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Basic and diluted EPS are computed independently for each of the periods presented. Accordingly, the sum of the quarterly EPS amounts may not
agree to the total for the year.</I></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>88</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=89,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=193985,FOLIO='88',FILE='DISK126:[06CHI5.06CHI1135]EE1135A.;14',USER='SPAPPON',CD=';8-MAR-2006;11:26' -->
<A NAME="page_ee1135_1_89"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed in Note&nbsp;13. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Income Taxes</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, Kraft has recognized income tax benefits in the consolidated statements of earnings during
2005 and 2004 as a result of various tax events, including the benefits earned under the provisions of the American Jobs Creation Act. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;20.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent Event:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January&nbsp;2006, the Company announced plans to continue its restructuring efforts beyond those originally contemplated (see Note&nbsp;3. </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset Impairment,
Exit and Implementation Costs</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>). Additional pre-tax charges are anticipated to be $2.5&nbsp;billion from 2006 to 2009, of
which approximately $1.6&nbsp;billion are expected to require cash payments. These charges will result in the anticipated closure of up to 20 additional facilities and the elimination of
approximately 8,000 additional positions. Initiatives under the expanded program include additional organizational
streamlining and facility closures. The entire restructuring program is expected to ultimately result in $3.7&nbsp;billion in pre-tax charges, the closure of up to 40 facilities and the
elimination of approximately 14,000 positions. Approximately $2.3&nbsp;billion of the $3.7&nbsp;billion in pre-tax charges are expected to require cash payments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ee1135_item_9._changes_in_and_disagre__ite03557"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ee1135_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 9.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Changes in and Disagreements with Accountants on Accounting and Financial Disclosure.    <BR>    </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;None. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ee1135_item_9a._controls_and_procedures."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ee1135_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 9A.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Controls and Procedures.    <BR>    </I></B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company carried out an evaluation, with the participation of the Company's management, including the Company's Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial
Officer, of the effectiveness of the Company's disclosure controls and procedures (pursuant to Rule&nbsp;13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended) as of the end of
the period covered by this report. Based upon that evaluation, the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that the Company's disclosure controls and procedures are effective.
Our management evaluated, with the participation of the Company's Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, any change in the Company's internal control over financial reporting and
determined that there has been no change in the Company's internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 that has materially affected, or is reasonably
likely to materially affect, the Company's internal control over financial reporting. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
also "Report of Management on Internal Control over Financial Reporting" in Item&nbsp;8. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ee1135_item_9b._other_information."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ee1135_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 9B.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Other Information.    <BR>    </I></B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;None. </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All
of the above-named officers have been employed by the Company in various capacities during the past five years, except for Mr.&nbsp;Firestone, Ms.&nbsp;Hefner, and
Ms.&nbsp;May. Prior to joining the Company in 2003, Mr.&nbsp;Firestone was Senior Vice President and General Counsel for Philip Morris International&nbsp;Inc. From 1998 until 2001, he was Chief
Counsel for Philip Morris Europe. Prior to joining the Company in 2004, Ms.&nbsp;Hefner held various positions with the Sara Lee Corporation since 1989. Most recently, she served as Chief Executive
Officer of Sara Lee Underwear, Socks&nbsp;&amp; Latin America Group. Prior to joining the Company in 2005, Ms.&nbsp;May held various positions with Baxter International,&nbsp;Inc. From 2001 to 2005,
she was Corporate Vice President of Human Resources. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has adopted a code of ethics as defined in Item 406 of Regulation&nbsp;S-K, which code applies to all of its employees, including its principal executive
officer, principal financial officer, principal accounting officer or controller, and persons performing similar functions. This code of ethics, which is entitled The Kraft Foods Code of Conduct for
Compliance and Integrity, is available free of charge on the Company's website at www.kraft.com and will be provided free of charge to any stockholder requesting a copy by writing to: Corporate
Secretary, Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., Three Lakes Drive, Northfield, IL 60093. Any waiver granted by the Company to its principal executive officer, principal financial officer, principal accounting
officer or controller under the code of ethics, or certain amendments to the code of ethics, will be disclosed on the Company's website at www.kraft.com. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, the Company has adopted corporate governance guidelines and charters for its Audit Committee, Compensation Committee and Nominating and Governance Committee, as well as a
code of business conduct and ethics that applies to the members of its Board of Directors. All of these materials are available on the Company's website at www.kraft.com and will be provided free of
charge to any stockholder requesting a copy by writing to: Corporate Secretary, Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., Three Lakes Drive, Northfield, IL&nbsp;60093. Certain of these materials may also be found in
the proxy statement relating to the Company's 2006 Annual Meeting of Stockholders. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
information on the Company's website is not, and shall not be deemed to be, a part of this Report or incorporated into any other filings the Company makes with the SEC. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
May&nbsp;24, 2005, the Company filed its Annual CEO Certification as required by Section&nbsp;303A.12 of the New York Stock Exchange Listed Company Manual. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
also Item&nbsp;11 for certain information that is incorporated by reference into this Item&nbsp;10. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="el1135_item_11._executive_compensation."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_el1135_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 11.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Executive Compensation.    <BR>    </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Except for the information relating to the executive officers of, and certain documents adopted by, the Company set forth in Item&nbsp;10 of this Report and the
information regarding equity compensation plans set forth in Item 12 below, the information called for by Items&nbsp;10-14 is hereby incorporated by reference to the Company's definitive
proxy statement for use in connection with its annual meeting of shareholders to be held on April&nbsp;25, 2006, filed with the SEC on March&nbsp;10, 2006, and, except as indicated therein, is
made a part hereof. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>91</FONT></P>

<A NAME="toc_ji1135_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM<BR>  ON FINANCIAL STATEMENT SCHEDULE    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>To
the Board of Directors and Shareholders of<BR>
Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc.: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
audits of the consolidated financial statements, of management's assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting and of the effectiveness of internal
control over financial reporting referred to in our report dated February&nbsp;7, 2006 appearing in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K of Kraft Foods Inc. also included an audit of
the financial statement schedule listed in Item 15(a) of this Form&nbsp;10-K. In our opinion, this financial statement schedule presents fairly, in all material respects, the information
set forth therein when read in conjunction with the related consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>/s/
</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS LLP </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Chicago, Illinois<BR>
February&nbsp;7, 2006 </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>S-1</FONT></P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Col.&nbsp;E</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Notes:</B></FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily
related to divestitures, acquisitions and currency translation.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Represents
charges for which allowances were created. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>S-2</FONT></P>

<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>KRAFT FOODS&nbsp;INC. SUBSIDIARIES    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

considered in the aggregate would not constitute a significant subsidiary, have been omitted. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>EXHIBIT 23  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="kc1306_consent_of_independent___kc102325"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_kc1306_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>CONSENT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We hereby consent to the incorporation by reference in the Registration Statements on Form&nbsp;S-8 (File Nos. 333-71266,
333-84616, and 333-125992) of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. (the "Company") and in the Company's Registration Statements on Form&nbsp;S-3 (File Nos.
333-67770, 333-86478, 333-101829 and 333-113620), of our reports dated February&nbsp;7, 2006 relating to the consolidated financial statements,
management's assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting and the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting and financial statement schedule, which
appear in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>EXHIBIT 24  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ke1306_power_of_attorney"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ke1306_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>POWER OF ATTORNEY    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The undersigned, a Director of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., a Virginia corporation (the "Company"), does hereby constitute and appoint Louis&nbsp;C. Camilleri,
Marc&nbsp;S. Firestone and James P. Dollive, or any one or more of them, his true and lawful attorney, for him and in his name, place and stead, to execute, by manual or facsimile signature,
electronic transmission or otherwise, the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K of the Company for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and any amendments or supplements to said Annual
Report and to cause the same to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, together with any exhibits, financial statements and schedules included or to be incorporated by reference
therein, hereby granting to said attorneys full power and authority to do and perform all and every act and thing whatsoever requisite or desirable to be done in and about the premises as fully to all
intents and purposes as the undersigned might or could do in person, hereby ratifying and confirming all acts and things which said attorneys may do or cause to be done by virtue of these present. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IN
WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned has hereunto set his hand and seal this 26th day of February, 2006. </FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=6,EFW="2168110",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="4",CHK=774841,FOLIO='blank',FILE='DISK122:[06CHI6.06CHI1306]KE1306A.;6',USER='ABLIJDE',CD=';6-MAR-2006;14:50' -->
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><B>POWER OF ATTORNEY  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The undersigned, a Director of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., a Virginia corporation (the "Company"), does hereby constitute and appoint Louis C. Camilleri,
Marc&nbsp;S. Firestone and James&nbsp;P. Dollive, or any one or more of them, her true and lawful attorney, for her and in her name, place and stead, to execute, by manual or facsimile signature,
electronic transmission or otherwise, the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K of the Company for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and any amendments or supplements to said Annual
Report and to cause the same to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, together with any exhibits, financial statements and schedules included or to be incorporated by reference
therein, hereby granting to said attorneys full power and authority to do and perform all and every act and thing whatsoever requisite or desirable to be done in and about the premises as fully to all
intents and purposes as the undersigned might or could do in person, hereby ratifying and confirming all acts and things which said attorneys may do or cause to be done by virtue of these present. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IN
WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned has hereunto set her hand and seal this 26th day of February, 2006. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><B>POWER OF ATTORNEY  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The undersigned, a Director of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., a Virginia corporation (the "Company"), does hereby constitute and appoint Louis C. Camilleri,
Marc&nbsp;S. Firestone and James&nbsp;P. Dollive, or any one or more of them, his true and lawful attorney, for him and in his name, place and stead, to execute, by manual or facsimile signature,
electronic transmission or otherwise, the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K of the Company for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and any amendments or supplements to said Annual
Report and to cause the same to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, together with any exhibits, financial statements and schedules included or to be incorporated by reference
therein, hereby granting to said attorneys full power and authority to do and perform all and every act and thing whatsoever requisite or desirable to be done in and about the premises as fully to all
intents and purposes as the undersigned might or could do in person, hereby ratifying and confirming all acts and things which said attorneys may do or cause to be done by virtue of these present. </FONT></P>

WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned has hereunto set his hand and seal this 26th day of February, 2006. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><B>POWER OF ATTORNEY  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The undersigned, a Director of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., a Virginia corporation (the "Company"), does hereby constitute and appoint Louis C. Camilleri,
Marc&nbsp;S. Firestone and James&nbsp;P. Dollive, or any one or more of them, her true and lawful attorney, for her and in her name, place and stead, to execute, by manual or facsimile signature,
electronic transmission or otherwise, the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K of the Company for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and any amendments or supplements to said Annual
Report and to cause the same to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, together with any exhibits, financial statements and schedules included or to be incorporated by reference

intents and purposes as the undersigned might or could do in person, hereby ratifying and confirming all acts and things which said attorneys may do or cause to be done by virtue of these present. </FONT></P>

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-31.1
<SEQUENCE>5
<FILENAME>a2168110zex-31_1.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EXHIBIT 31.1
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
</HEAD>
<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF" LINK=BLUE  VLINK=PURPLE>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=3 ><A HREF="#06CHI1135_5">QuickLinks</A></FONT>
<font size=3> -- Click here to rapidly navigate through this document</font>
<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>EXHIBIT 31.1  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="kg1306_certifications"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_kg1306_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Certifications    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>I,
Roger K. Deromedi, certify that: </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>1.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>I
have reviewed this annual report on Form&nbsp;10-K of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc.;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>2.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on my knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light of the
circumstances under which such statements were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this report;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>3.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this report;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>4.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
registrant's other certifying officer and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act
Rules&nbsp;13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules&nbsp;13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f))
for the registrant and have:
<BR><BR></FONT>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Designed
such disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material information relating
to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Designed
such internal control over financial reporting, or caused such internal control over financial reporting to be designed under our supervision, to provide reasonable assurance
regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(c)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Evaluated
the effectiveness of the registrant's disclosure controls and procedures and presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and
procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this report based on such evaluation; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(d)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Disclosed
in this report any change in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the registrant's most recent fiscal quarter (the registrant's
fourth fiscal quarter in the case of an annual report) that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the registrant's internal control over financial reporting; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD></DL>
</DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>5.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
registrant's other certifying officer and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant's auditors and the
audit committee of the registrant's board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):
<BR><BR></FONT>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>All
significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect the
registrant's ability to record, process, summarize and report financial information; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Any
fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting. </FONT></DD></DL>
</DD></DL>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="40%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
Date: March&nbsp;10, 2006</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="58%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
/s/&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>ROGER K. DEROMEDI</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><HR NOSHADE><FONT SIZE=2> Roger K. Deromedi<BR>
Chief Executive Officer</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A

<A NAME="toc_ki1306_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Certifications    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>I,
James P. Dollive, certify that: </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>1.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>I
have reviewed this annual report on Form&nbsp;10-K of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc.;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>2.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on my knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light of the
circumstances under which such statements were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this report;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>3.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this report;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>4.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
registrant's other certifying officer and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act
Rules&nbsp;13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules&nbsp;13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f))
for the registrant and have:
<BR><BR></FONT>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Designed
such disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material information relating
to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Designed
such internal control over financial reporting, or caused such internal control over financial reporting to be designed under our supervision, to provide reasonable assurance
regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(c)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Evaluated
the effectiveness of the registrant's disclosure controls and procedures and presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and
procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this report based on such evaluation; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(d)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Disclosed
in this report any change in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the registrant's most recent fiscal quarter (the registrant's
fourth fiscal quarter in the case of an annual report) that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the registrant's internal control over financial reporting; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD></DL>
</DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>5.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
registrant's other certifying officer and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant's auditors and the
audit committee of the registrant's board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):
<BR><BR></FONT>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>All
significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect the
registrant's ability to record, process, summarize and report financial information; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Any
fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting. </FONT></DD></DL>
</DD></DL>

<DESCRIPTION>EXHIBIT 32.1
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
</HEAD>
<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF" LINK=BLUE  VLINK=PURPLE>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=3 ><A HREF="#06CHI1135_7">QuickLinks</A></FONT>
<font size=3> -- Click here to rapidly navigate through this document</font>
<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>EXHIBIT 32.1  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="kk1306_certification_pursuant_to_18_u__cer03819"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_kk1306_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>CERTIFICATION PURSUANT TO<BR>  18 U.S.C. SECTION 1350,<BR>  AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO<BR>  SECTION 906 OF THE SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the Annual Report of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. (the "Company") on Form&nbsp;10-K for the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 as
filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof (the "Report"), I, Roger&nbsp;K. Deromedi, Chief Executive Officer of the Company, certify, pursuant to 18&nbsp;U.S.C.
&sect;&nbsp;1350, as adopted pursuant to &sect;&nbsp;906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(1)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the
Report fully complies with the requirements of section&nbsp;13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934; and </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(2)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the
information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company. </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="40%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
/s/&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>ROGER K. DEROMEDI</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><HR NOSHADE><FONT SIZE=2> Roger K. Deromedi<BR>
Chief Executive Officer<BR>
March 10, 2006</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="58%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>A signed original of this written statement required by Section&nbsp;906, or other document authenticating, acknowledging, or otherwise
adopting the signature that appears in typed form within the electronic version of this written statement required by Section&nbsp;906, has been provided to Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. and will be
retained by Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. and furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission or its staff upon request.</I></FONT></P>

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-32.2
<SEQUENCE>8
<FILENAME>a2168110zex-32_2.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EXHIBIT 32.2
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
</HEAD>
<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF" LINK=BLUE  VLINK=PURPLE>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=3 ><A HREF="#06CHI1135_8">QuickLinks</A></FONT>
<font size=3> -- Click here to rapidly navigate through this document</font>
<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>EXHIBIT 32.2  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="km1306_certification_pursuant_to_18_u__cer03819"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_km1306_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>CERTIFICATION PURSUANT TO<BR>  18 U.S.C. SECTION 1350,<BR>  AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO<BR>  SECTION 906 OF THE SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the Annual Report of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. (the "Company") on Form&nbsp;10-K for the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 as
filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof (the "Report"), I, James&nbsp;P. Dollive, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of the Company, certify, pursuant
to 18&nbsp;U.S.C. &sect;&nbsp;1350, as adopted pursuant to &sect;&nbsp;906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that: </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(1)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the
Report fully complies with the requirements of section&nbsp;13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934; and </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(2)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the
information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company. </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
